text: Oh
sir left foot the son of Chico dusty
good boy it's so freakin hot I need
someone to cool me down maybe this will
work
I feel cooler but I don't feel cooler hi
my needle drops Anthony Fantino
Internet's busiest music nerd it's time
for an album review big boys new album
sir left foot the son of Chico dusty
well big boy is a Georgia MCM producer
who's best known for his work in one of
the longest-running rap duo's Outkast
duh and I like many of you had my early
years peppered with hits like bombs over
Baghdad and so fresh so clean and of
course miss Jackson but their early
stuff like is just a hip-hop classic
really beefy drumbeats heavy bass and
memorable samples from 70s funk and soul
and of course Andre and big boy at the
time were just standout personalities
with abrasive words but they didn't
really dip into the world of gangsta rap
amen Outkast more recent albums are just
notorious for being all over the place
and it's no less true for this thing sir
lucious left foot is powered by a ton of
influences but Big Boi is not afraid to
flaunt them throughout the album he
makes references to Michael Jackson care
as one wu-tang clan the ghetto boys and
the production is kind of derivative to
for example just on one track alone one
of my favorites shutterbug we have a
hook that kind of reminds me of that
classic hip hop song the bubble Bunch
some really retro since they actually
borrow a hook from a soul to soul song
at one point back to now and the beat on
this song the rhythm sounds eerily close
to Jake wands tipsy it's really tough to
keep this album review at a certain
amount of time but still do each song
justice because every track kind of goes
in a different direction this album is
pulled all over the
place not only by its guest MCS and
singers like the alt rap band Vonnegut
Janelle Monae is on here Jamie Foxx
George Clinton just name a few but
there's also little to no cohesion in
the production department too we have
beats from organized Noize who of course
have been there since the beginning of
Outkast career mr. DJ Little John Andre
3000 Scott Storch and those are just a
couple names that you'll see in the
production credits and this leads to a
lot of inconsistency which is kind of
refreshing at first hearing a lot of
different things
kind of like a Tabas tree tapestry oh
and I got to give it to Big Boi for
basically putting together an album with
no two songs that sound alike but I
can't help but feel as if this album at
some points isn't so much worried about
producing a decent song as it is getting
the credit of that singer getting the
credit of that emcee getting the credit
of that producer just to sort of have it
on their just pad this album with cameos
and appearances as opposed to just
putting together a good Feist solid
Feist record fight as usual big boys
flow is just nasty clever wordplay and
sometimes the way he says things is more
interesting than what he's actually
saying just manipulating words to make
rhymes fit make syllables fit together
out of all the things that I might not
have liked about this album I have to
say that Big Boy's rhymes his
presentation his personality aside from
a little bit of tough-guy bull slinked
not a lot of complaints this album as a
typical as it is is too typical of a
story for me
because the first few tracks on thing
are fantastic I'm loving it but it just
turns into a drought in the middle in
the vicinity of the track tangerine in
that second third of the album big boy
is still rapping like a champ but I'm
really not diggin the songs or the
production all that much some tracks get
really sappy while others too
flaunt obnoxiously bad hooks and on a
few spots with this album it feels as if
the weight of the world has just put on
the guest singer or guest MCS shoulders
to sort of carry the whole track but
it's just not working
however the LP does redeem itself with
shine blockers which is sounding remixed
and resurrected that track just has a
really soulful hook these really deep
pit shifted vocals that I love
thankfully so the left foot and strong
just as it starts strong but there are
too many tracks I don't like for me to
love this entire album I know big boys
not a one-dimensional guy so I'm just
kind of confused as to why he produced
an album with so many one-dimensional
songs but if you're looking for a rap
record that's pretty much a party album
something with a lot of different
production styles something with a lot
of different guests emcees and singers
and producers this may be where you want
to be but what do you think of this
album do you love it
do you hate it and why let me know
Anthony Fantino here the needle drop big
boy thanks for watching for it
